message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Lisinopril is known to cause cough and increase serum potassium levels, whereas the others are not known to cause these symptoms. Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor commonly used to treat hypertension and heart failure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Lisinopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor commonly used for hypertension and can cause cough as a side effect. ACE inhibitors can also increase serum potassium levels in patients with renal insufficiency or those taking potassium-sparing diuretics. Furosemide is a loop diuretic that can cause hypokalemia. Amiodarone and digoxin do not commonly cause cough or affect potassium levels.

Furosemide is a diuretic and can cause electrolyte imbalances but not cough. Amiodarone and digoxin are used to treat arrhythmias and do not typically cause cough or hyperkalemia.

Lisinopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor commonly used to treat hypertension and its side effects include cough and hyperkalemia. Furosemide is a loop diuretic used to treat edema associated with heart failure, Amiodarone is used to treat arrhythmias, and Digoxin is used to treat heart failure and atrial fibrillation. None of these medications are known to cause cough and hyperkalemia as side effects.

Furosemide, Amiodarone, and Digoxin can all have side effects, but they are not commonly associated with cough or increased serum potassium levels.
